In February of 1953, the first Governor's Advisory Committee on Educational
Television met under the co-chairmanship of Dr. John Bartky of Stanford Uni¬
versity and Mr. William Joyce of Pasadena. Throughout the year it continued to
meet, gathering information and advising fledgling community organizations, and
by November it had prepared its recommendations for Governor Warren (see Appen¬
dix A). In February of the following year it resubmitted these recommendations
to his successor, Governor Knight, with the added recommendation that the committee
be kept in existence another year in order to complete its work. Governor Knight
did not act to continue the committee and it went out of existence early in 1954.
In the meantime, on November 1, 1953, the first educational channel in Cali¬
fornia (and the second in the nation) began broadcasting in Los Angeles under
the stewardship of the Alan Hancock Foundation of the University of Southern
California. The distinction of being first in the State was too soon offset by
another, less happy, distinction: it was the first and only educational tele¬
vision station in the nation to leave the air permanently. The reasons for its
failure had little to do with the nature of educational television. Broad¬
casting upon an ultra high frequency channel (Channel 28) in an area thoroughly
saturated with seven standard band commercial television stations, it was unable
to attract enough audience to justify its operating expenses. The reason for
the small audience may be found in the need for each viewer to invest an addi¬
tional thirty or more dollars in receiving equipment in order to receive what
was, in the Los Angeles area, an eighth channel.
In the northern part of the State two community organizations which had been
formed in the Bay Area and in San Jose, merged in 1952 to form the Bay Area
Educational Television Association, and by the summer of 1954 had established
KQED (Channel 9) as one of the pioneers and subsequent leaders in the educa¬
